fullText: F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1925 novel “The Great Gatsby,” which captured the roaring twenties with shocking clarity, is a staple of high school curricula and has been immortalized in two famous film adaptations (in 1974 by Richard Clayton and in 2013 by Baz Lurhman). It's most remembered for the titular character's lavish parties, though as any good reader of the novel will tell you, the party's are all razzle dazzle — what really matters is what's underneath. The pain, the social climbing, the lack of ethics, and the post-war, orgiastic egoism are what the work is really about.
dtliExcerpt: While the show boasts stunning visuals and impressive performances, particularly from Jeremy Jordan as Jay Gatsby and Eva Noblezada as Daisy Buchanan, the musical struggles to capture the tragic essence of Fitzgerald's masterpiece.
showScoreExcerpt: While the show boasts stunning visuals and impressive performances, particularly from Jeremy Jordan as Jay Gatsby and Eva Noblezada as Daisy Buchanan, the musical struggles to capture the tragic essence of Fitzgerald's masterpiece.
